headline: Paid Notice: Deaths RAVOSA, CARMINO
summary: RAVOSA--Carmino, one of the most popular songwriters for children and foremost musical composer on historical subjects, died on July 19th at age 85. Born in Springfield, MA, he graduated from Hartt School of Music and Columbia University; was a music teacher at Fox Meadow School in Scarsdale, NY; then Faculty Fellow and Composer-In-Residence at The Dalton School and subsequently for Edison Schools. At the invitation of President Jimmy Carter, Ravosa performed his musical "Ghosts in the White House" at the White House in 1978. He also performed at the inaugurations of President George H.W. Bush in 1989 and President George W. Bush in 2001. His musical "Scarecrow" won awards in 1975 at the International Light Opera Festival in Ireland, and his musical "Seneca Falls" was performed in 1976 at Carnegie Hall. He also performed at the gala reopening of the Ellis Island Immigration Museum in 2001. He was an author for Silver Burdett's music textbook series and for CBS's "Captain Kangaroo", "Romper Room" and PBS's "Shining Time Station". He is survived by his wife Claire; children Carine, Gina and Dean; eight grandchildren; and sister Corena. Visiting hours are July 23rd from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Beecher Flooks Funeral Home in Pleasantville, NY. A Memorial Service will be held August 8th at 11am at Emanuel Lutheran Church in Pleasantville, NY. 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths PFIZER, BERYL ANN
summary: PFIZER--Beryl Ann. Writer and radio and television producer, died February 12, 2016, of natural causes in her beloved Manhattan brownstone. She was 87, born in 1928, in Morristown NJ. She was predeceased by her father, William R. Pfizer, Vice President of The Panama Line, and her mother, Isabel Morin Pfizer. Beryl grew up in Mt. Lakes, NJ, graduating from Mt. Lakes High School in 1945 and from Hood College in 1949, with a BA in music. She always wanted to live in the city, and moved to Manhattan after college to begin a long and varied career in the radio and television industries. She worked for the Arthur Godfrey Show on CBS-TV, wrote for NBC TV's The Home Show and worked with Dave Garroway on NBC TV's The Today Show, where she was a "Today Girl" feature panelist (1960-61). She received three Emmy Award nominations (1980-82), and won an Emmy in 1980, for producing "Ask NBC News, with John Chancellor." She wrote for NBC TV's broadcasts of The Macy's Thanksgiving Parade (1987-89), for NBC's MONITOR Radio, and for Edwin Newman; imagine the challenge of writing for the author of "Strictly Speaking!" She worked for NBC News at many Democratic National Conventions, including 1968 in Chicago. She produced "The Women's Program" series for the NBC Radio Network, which received a commendation from American Women in Radio and Television in 1979. Beryl also wrote and produced NBC-TV's "The All- New Pink Panther Show" (1971-74), which featured those famous cartoons and live-action segments with The Ritts Puppets and comedian Lenny Schultz reading letters and jokes from viewers. She produced medical and health stories for the NBC flagship TV station in New York City. She was the author of "Poor Woman's Almanac", humorous and pithy quips published in Ladies Home Journal. She received the Distinguished Alumni Award from Hood College, where she sponsored scholarships in writing and theater arts. Beryl was also an avid athlete and enjoyed playing tennis. She took up running and unexpectedly won prizes in the upper age groups of Jersey Shore 5 K's for many years, which tickled her to no end. She was proud to have completed a New York City marathon, and she loved the Midnight Run on New Year's Eve in Central Park, running her last race just last month. Beryl was generous, quietly helping many people. Terence Cardinal Cooke Healthcare Center awarded her the Mary P. Clark award for exceptional care and volunteer work for the Huntington's Disease unit of the hospital. She is survived by her sister, Joan Pfizer Sussmann, her four nieces and nephews, and five grand nieces and grand nephews. The family will hold a private memorial. In lieu of flowers, please honor Beryl by donating to your favorite charity. 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths DURKIN, JERRY
summary:
DURKIN--Jerry, 71, of Greentown, PA died on September 11th. He had a distinguished 34-year career at CBS Records/SONY Music Entertainment. He won a Peabody Award, an Emmy Award and several Cable ACE Awards. He is survived by his wife Geraldine as well as four children: Kathleen, Scranton, PA; Michael (Abbie), Rye, NY; Kevin (Kristina) Manhattan Beach,CA; Meghan Torrillo (Tom), Darien, CT; grandsons Riley, Jake, Graham, Tommy and Archie; brother James and sister, Margaret (Jack) Curtis. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Royal Scholarship Fund, Univ. of Scranton, PO Box 1385, Scranton, PA 18501 or the Tafton Volunteer Ambulance Corps., 235 Rte 507, PO Box 5, Tafton, PA 18464. Funeral services can be found at

http://www.odonnellfuneral com.

Paid Notice: Deaths HIRSCH, BERNARD "BUD"
summary: HIRSCH--Bernard "Bud", 85, passed away peacefully on September 29, 2014. He worked as a television executive for both CBS and NBC from the '50s to the '90s, and, after retirement, traveled the world. He enjoyed travel, food, and his family. He will be missed. He leaves behind his brother (Herbert), two sons (Peter and Richard), three daughters-in-law (Jill, Diane, Bridgette), five grandchildren (Katharine, David, Noah, Rebecca, Graham) and his loving wife Peggy. Services will be at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, 3:30pm on Sunday October 5th.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LUDLUM, MICHAEL
summary:
LUDLUM--Michael C.

Died November 29, with loving wife, Melissa, daughter, Catherine, and son, Gregory, by his side. Beloved brother of June Blake. Long-time CBS Radio news executive and NYU journalism professor, much respected and admired by friends, colleagues and students. Memorial service Friday, December 4, at 10:30am at Grace Episcopal Church, 200 Highfield Lane, Nutley. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration, (theaftd.org).

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths PILSNER, JOYCE
summary: PILSNER--Joyce, died April 14 2016. A native of NYC, she excelled in school graduating at 15 from Hunter High School and at 19 from Hunter College. She earned an MA from Columbia and a Certificate in Business Management from Columbia Business School. Her career began as a NYC High School science teacher and guidance counselor, then an administrator at Sarah Lawrence, then becoming Executive Director of Riverdale Mental Health Association for 35 years where she developed services for both youth and adults. She was devoted to her community and served as Chair of CB8 on which she sat for 25 years. She helped found The Coalition as well as Riverdale Senior Services and received many awards, including Riverdalian of the Year. Predeceased by her beloved Harry, she is survived by her daughter Toby and granddaughters Ariel and Halley whom she adored, as well as her sister Rhoda, niece Amy, nephews Scott and Alan and their families. 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WALLING, MARY ALICE
summary: WALLING--Mary Alice, 72, passed away on September 26 at Mount Sinai Hospital after suffering a brain aneurism. Mary lived an extraordinary life which took her through several careers and locations. She grew up in Millburn, NJ and graduated from Millburn High school. She graduated from Manhattanville College in Purchase, NY and moved to Manhattan in the mid 1960's. She worked in book publishing, spent a year in Munich, Germany and returned to New York City to pursue opportunities as a dancer on Broadway. This included a road tour with The National Touring Company production of "Coco" with Katherine Hepburn as well as stints in The Bahamas and Puerto Rico. Following her dancing career she earned her MBA from Columbia Business School in 1978. She was employed by CBS for a period before taking a position as Corporate Treasurer with Sotheby's where she worked for many years in New York City and London. Later she became the Chief Operating Officer of the Jewish Museum in New York City and retired in 2011. At the time of her death she was working part time with the Electronic Arts Intermix, a nonprofit arts organization. Mary had a broad range of interests including travel, sports, theater and international affairs. She was an avid skier and tennis player. Mary was predeceased by her parents Alfred and Alice Walling of Millburn, New Jersey and by her brother John Walling of Muskegon, Michigan. She is survived by her brother Michael Walling of Kansas City, Missouri, her nieces Martha Ellinwood of Westport, Connecticut, Amy Engel of San Diego, California and her nephew Mark Walling of Kansas City, Missouri. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held at The Greenwich Village Funeral Home in New York City on November 1st at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to 350.org, The North Shore Animal League or Career Transition for Dancers.

headline: Love The Coopers: Santa's Army Of Helpers
Paid Notice: Deaths BLUMBERG, RHODA
summary:
BLUMBERG--Rhoda.

Died at home on June 6th at age 98. Award-winning author of non-fiction for young adults; enthusiastic wife, mother, grandmother and friend. Raised in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. After graduating from Adelphi College in 1937, Rhoda became a "career girl". She produced several programs for CBS radio and later wrote feature articles for several national magazines. In 1944, she met Gerald Blumberg, a successful attorney, and they married six months later. Moving from Brooklyn in 1951 to a farm in what was then a rural part of Westchester County, Rhoda dedicated the next 20+ years to raising their four children. She enjoyed teaching her children the joys of nature and sharing her passion for classical music, travel and tennis. When her youngest child entered college in the early 1970s, her interest in history and the exhilaration of research triumphed, and Rhoda returned to her typewriter. During the next 30 years, she wrote and composed over 25 non-fiction books. She had an uncanny ability to find and incorporate fascinating anecdotes that brought history to life for millions of young adults (and their parents). Her books received numerous awards, including the Boston Globe Horn Book Award, the Newbery Honor Medal, Orbis Pictus Award for Outstanding Non-Fiction for Children, and multiple Golden Kite awards. Her books included "Commodore Perry in the Land of the Shogun" (1985), "The Incredible Journey of Lewis and Clark" (1987), "The Great American Gold Rush" (1989), "Shipwrecked! The True Adventures of a Japanese Boy" (2001), and "York's Adventures with Lewis and Clark: An African-American's Part in the Great Expedition" (2004). Rhoda also partnered on several books with friend and renowned illustrator, Murray Tinkelman, including "The Truth About Dragons" (1980) and "Backyard Bestiary" (1979). Jerry Blumberg died in 2009 shortly after their 64th wedding anniversary. Rhoda's life is celebrated by a large family, including four children and their spouses: Larry Blumberg and Robin Lynn, Rena Blumberg, Alice and David Rubin, and Leda Blumberg and Steve Cole; nine grandchildren: Daniel Blumberg, Carla Steckman, Ilana Blumberg, William Gottlieb, Osheana Tashombe, Gregory Rubin, Amalia Rubin, Dana Rocco and Eliza Volk; ten great-grand- children; and her best friend and sister, Cynthia. She is the last to pass of her Adelphi College gang: Betty, Estelle, Gladys, Mickey, Mimi, and Norma. Funeral will be on Friday, June 10, 2016 at 11am at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, Glengary Road, Croton-on-Hudson, NY. Burial will follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. Shiva plans will be announced at the funeral.

Paid Notice: Deaths LAVINE, MELVIN
summary:
LAVINE--Melvin (Mel),

88, a gifted print and television journalist, died in Berkeley, CA, on July 5. A producer- writer for NBC and CBS News, he was raised in Brookline, MA, and graduated from the University of Maine. He became a reporter for Sanford Maine's Tribune in 1950 and later the Humboldt Times in Eureka, CA. In the 1960s, he was a news anchor for a Eureka TV station before winning a fellowship at Columbia University School of Journalism. In 1964, he joined NBC News in New York, assigned to local programs and The Today Show. In 1978, he switched to CBS's Sunday Morning and Walter Cronkite's documentary unit. Moving in 1991 to Berkeley, he continued as a producer with CBS. Mel's memoir, "A Strange Breed of Folks," is a vivid account of his career. Until his death, he was a columnist for The San Leandro, CA, Times. Predeceased by his first wife, Donna Willbanks, he is survived by his wife, Lorraine (Rainey) Sykes.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WINDT, ROBERT
summary: WINDT--Robert. He was born April 27, 1920 and died October 24, 2014. Robert Stanley Windt was bred in Brooklyn. He was a graduate of New Utrecht High School and a life-long baseball fan having seen the Dodgers play at Ebbets Field. He joined the Army for World War II becoming a carburation expert and B-29 Bomber instructor. At the end of the War, he returned home to live with his mother and start a career in public relations working for such companies as CBS, Mountain Valley Water, Dumont Television, Fairchild Publications, Pepsi Cola, Royal Crown Cola, Seagram's and STP Motor Oil. He retired from the profession when he and his two partners sold their ownership of Bebidas, a Spanish language beverage industry magazine. Uncle Bob, as he was known, was a loving, son, brother, uncle, great-uncle and great-great-uncle with a story or three at every family gathering. He will be missed by his family and friends. At the request of the family, donations in his memory can be made to the List Family Fund for Jewish Culture in Memory of Lawrence List at the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue (131 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201). To use Uncle Bob's favorite word - he had a "Fabulous" life. Bobye, Deborah and Mali List.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MOONVES, JOSEPHINE SCHLEIFER
summary: MOONVES--Josephine Schleifer, A beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, died peacefully surrounded by family on July 15 at UCLA Hospital in Santa Monica, CA. She was 92. Moonves, best known to friends as Jo, was a gifted caregiver, who finished Number One in her class at nursing school, before beginning a long career in the healthcare field. She continued to practice nursing until she retired at age 70. Outside of nursing, Moonves was an avid traveler, having visited nearly 50 countries on all seven continents during her lifetime. She was also an avid reader. She loved visiting museums, watching movies and dining out. Family was the focus of her life. She was the beloved matriarch for an extended family of nieces, nephews and cousins. Josephine Schleifer Moonves was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. She was the oldest of five children and was predeceased by her four siblings. She married Herman Moonves, an Army veteran, in 1943. After marrying, the couple moved to Valley Stream, NY to raise their family. Together, the couple had three sons, CBS Chairman and CEO, Leslie Moonves (Julie Chen Moonves), entertainment attorney Jonathan Moonves (Dianne Moonves), and Alan Moonves, and a daughter, Melissa Moonves (Yves Colon). They later moved to Lynchburg, VA, Atlanta, GA and then to Pacific Palisades, CA in 1979. In California, Josephine and Herman were active members of the Santa Monica Family YMCA. In addition to her two sons and daughter, Josephine Moonves is survived by her husband of 73 years, Herman, plus eight grandchildren: Adam, Sara, Michael, Charlie, Jacques, Ian, Alaina, and Julia, and three great- grandchildren: Noah, Judah and Jack. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in Josephine's name to the Alliance for Children's Rights, 3333 Wilshire Blvd, Suite 500, Los Angeles, CA 90010. (https://support.kids- alliance. org/Josephine MoonvesMemorial) 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LANGSDORF, JOHN J.
summary: LANGSDORF--John Jeffrey, 85, died on August 30, 2014 in New York City. John was the the loving husband of Constance K. Berman, adored father of Robin B. Langsdorf and Holly L. Hatch and her husband Andrew Hatch, and beloved "Bapa" of granddaughters Kelsey and Sophie Hatch. His brother, Roger, and his wife Juel Janus will dearly miss him, as will several nieces and nephews. John was the devoted stepfather of Patricia (Greg Koerper), Anthony (Jill Remaly), Anne and Donald (Meredith Moss) Berman and the cherished step grandfather of eight. Born September 12, 1928, John attended Horace Mann School and Oberlin College. After proudly serving in the US Army, he worked in Philadelphia at WCAU-TV, an early CBS affiliate where he met his late wife, Doris Magnus. They lived in Montclair, NJ for forty years. John worked for many years at American Sponge & Chamois Co. and then Church and Dwight Co. before retiring and moving back to Manhattan, his birthplace. He traveled extensively, volunteered tirelessly and enjoyed the outdoors; especially his bike rides around Central Park. John was a lifelong supporter of the arts, and generously shared his love of music and theater with family and countless friends. He will be remembered as a gentle, kind, and thoughtful man who always put his family first. A memorial service will be held at the New York Society for Ethical Culture (NYSEC), 2 West 64th St., New York, NY 10023 on Saturday, September 6, 2014 at 2pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to the NYSEC (www.nysec.org) or to the Squam Lakes Association, PO Box 204, Holderness, NH 03245 (www.squamlakes.org).

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GORDON, ELLIOT M.
summary: GORDON--Elliot M.,90 passed away on October 11 after a long illness. He is survived by his loving partner of 36 years, Lynda Gould, his son, Miles, daughter-in-law, Vera (Bittner), sister, Lois Schneider, of Haverford, PA, brother-in-law Frank Gould, and sister-in-law, Janet Weinstein, of Philadelphia, and nieces Ellen Rothstein, Leah Garnett, Ruth Rothstein, Mollie Weinstein-Gould, Jordan Gould and nephew Jesse Gould. Elliot grew up in Philadelphia and received a B.A. and M.A. in Romance Languages from the University of Pennsylvania, class of '45. He served in the Navy and then studied at the Sorbonne from '47 to '49, where he perfected his French and his French accent. Elliot settled in New York City where he owned Stereo Lab in Greenwich Village, selling components and high end stereo equipment. He then went to work at CBS Television where he was an audio engineer for 35 years. He earned an Emmy in 1987 for technical work at NFL Today. Elliot was a bridge aficionado and Life Master. He was an early adapter of home computers, and initiated a course at Lenox Hill Neighborhood House to instruct seniors in their use which he taught as a volunteer. He collected rare and out-of-print books on the fine arts and enjoyed incorporating his book searches into his world travels. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Wright Center on Aging/NY Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center, 525 East 68 Street, NYC, 10065. 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BLUMBERG, RHODA
summary: BLUMBERG--Rhoda. Died at home on June 6th at age 98. Award-winning author of non-fiction for young adults; enthusiastic wife, mother, grandmother and friend. Raised in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. After graduating from Adelphi College in 1937, Rhoda became a "career girl". She produced several programs for CBS radio and later wrote feature articles for several national magazines. In 1944, she met Gerald Blumberg, a successful attorney, and they married six months later. Moving from Brooklyn in 1951 to a farm in what was then a rural part of Westchester County, Rhoda dedicated the next 20+ years to raising their four children. She enjoyed teaching her children the joys of nature and sharing her passion for classical music, travel and tennis. When her youngest child entered college in the early 1970s, her interest in history and the exhilaration of research triumphed, and Rhoda returned to her typewriter. During the next 30 years, she wrote and composed over 25 non-fiction books. She had an uncanny ability to find and incorporate fascinating anecdotes that brought history to life for millions of young adults (and their parents). Her books received numerous awards, including the Boston Globe Horn Book Award, the Newbery Honor Medal, Orbis Pictus Award for Outstanding Non-Fiction for Children, and multiple Golden Kite awards. Her books included "Commodore Perry in the Land of the Shogun" (1985), "The Incredible Journey of Lewis and Clark" (1987), "The Great American Gold Rush" (1989), "Shipwrecked! The True Adventures of a Japanese Boy" (2001), and "York's Adventures with Lewis and Clark: An African-American's Part in the Great Expedition" (2004). Rhoda also partnered on several books with friend and renowned illustrator, Murray Tinkelman, including "The Truth About Dragons" (1980) and "Backyard Bestiary" (1979). Jerry Blumberg died in 2009 shortly after their 64th wedding anniversary. Rhoda's life is celebrated by a large family, including four children and their spouses: Larry Blumberg and Robin Lynn, Rena Blumberg, Alice and David Rubin, and Leda Blumberg and Steve Cole; nine grandchildren: Daniel Blumberg, Carla Steckman, Ilana Blumberg, William Gottlieb, Osheana Tashombe, Gregory Rubin, Amalia Rubin, Dana Rocco and Eliza Volk; ten great-grand- children; and her best friend and sister, Cynthia. She is the last to pass of her Adelphi College gang: Betty, Estelle, Gladys, Mickey, Mimi, and Norma. Funeral will be on Friday, June 10, 2016 at 11am at Temple Israel of Northern Westchester, Glengary Road, Croton-on-Hudson, NY. Burial will follow at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. Shiva plans will be announced at the funeral. 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WALLING, MARY A.
summary: WALLING--Mary Alice, 72, passed away on September 26 at Mount Sinai Hospital after suffering a brain aneurism. Mary lived an extraordinary life which took her through several careers and locations. She grew up in Millburn, NJ and graduated from Millburn High school. She graduated from Manhattanville College in Purchase, NY and moved to Manhattan in the mid 1960's. She worked in book publishing, spent a year in Munich, Germany and returned to New York City to pursue opportunities as a dancer on Broadway. This included a road tour with The National Touring Company production of "Coco" with Katherine Hepburn as well as stints in The Bahamas and Puerto Rico. Following her dancing career she earned her MBA from Columbia Business School in 1978. She was employed by CBS for a period before taking a position as Corporate Treasurer with Sotheby's where she worked for many years in New York City and London. Later she became the Chief Operating Officer of the Jewish Museum in New York City and retired in 2011. At the time of her death she was working part time with the Electronic Arts Intermix, a nonprofit arts organization. Mary had a broad range of interests including travel, sports, theater and international affairs. She was an avid skier and tennis player. Mary was predeceased by her parents Alfred and Alice Walling of Millburn, New Jersey and by her brother John Walling of Muskegon, Michigan. She is survived by her brother Michael Walling of Kansas City, Missouri, her nieces Martha Ellinwood of Westport, Connecticut, Amy Engel of San Diego, California and her nephew Mark Walling of Kansas City, Missouri. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held at The Greenwich Village Funeral Home in New York City on November 1st at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to 350.org, The North Shore Animal League or Career Transition for Dancers.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BARUCH, RALPH M.
summary: BARUCH--Ralph M.,passed away on March 3, 2016 at the age of 92. Ralph was a founder of Viacom International Inc. and served as its President and CEO from 1971 to 1983 and as Chairman until July 1987. Ralph was born in Frankfurt, Germany. In 1933, as a young child, he was forced to flee from the Nazis with his family to Paris, where he was educated. In 1940, they then escaped Paris. A harrowing three-month journey through France ensued, and Ralph carried his grandmother over the Pyrenees mountains. Eventually, under the auspices of the International Rescue Committee, the family arrived in the United States in December, 1940. He began his communications career in radio and joined the DuMont Television Network in 1950. He moved to CBS in 1954, progressing to CBS Group President, prior to the inception of Viacom. Ralph was instrumental in spinning off Viacom from CBS in 1971. During his tenure, Viacom acquired cable television systems, initiated Showtime, The Cable Health Network (now Lifetime), MTV, Nickelodeon, The Movie Channel, VH-1, and bought back the half of Showtime which had previously been sold to Warner. Eventually, Viacom, in turn, acquired CBS. Ralph authored an autobiography, "Television Tightrope - How I Escaped Hitler, Survived CBS and Fathered Viacom," published in April 2007, and also wrote "How Broadcasting and Cable Happened (in spite of the FCC)." Mr. Baruch served as vice chairman of Carnegie Hall, as a member of its Executive Committee and as chairman or member of various committees of the Board of Trustees of the Hall. He was named an Honorary Trustee in 2007. He served as a member of the Board of WNET and was a Trustee and member of the Executive Committee of Northwell Health. He also served as a Trustee of the Museum of Television and Radio (now the Paley Center for Media). Ralph was a founder and a Fellow of the International Academy of Television Arts & Sciences and served on the Board and Executive Committee of the Academy. He was a past-President of both the International Radio & Television Society and its Foundation. In 1985 the IRTS honored him with its Gold Medal, one of the most prestigious awards in communications for his outstanding contributions to the industry. A former director and member of the Executive Committee of the National Cable Television Association, (now the National Cable & Telecommunications Association), Mr. Baruch served for seven years as Chairman of an NCTA committee instrumental in the passage by Congress of the Cable Act of 1984. Under President Reagan, Ralph served for seven years as Chairman of the USIA's Television Communications Board of Advisors and as a member of the President's International Youth Exchange Initiative. In 1988, he served as a Senior Fellow of the Freedom Forum at Columbia University. Ralph was a co-founder, immediate past Chairman and Chairman Emeritus of the National Academy of Cable Programming. He received the Academy's first "Governor's Award," recognizing his contributions to the development of cable programming. He received the cable television industry's highest honor, the Vanguard Award, three of the NCTA's President's Awards, and its Chairman of the Year Award. In 1994 Ralph was honored with a special award from the International Academy of Television Arts and in 1999, Walter Cronkite presented him with an Emmy for the International Academy of Television Arts& Sciences. Seven years later, he was inducted into the Cable Hall of Fame. Then, in 2011, Ralph was the inaugural recipient of the WNET Distinguished Service Award. Ralph was a co-founder of C- Span, and often testified before regulatory agencies and committees of the Senate and House. He also served as Chairman of the NCTA's Pay Cable Committee, instrumental in removing FCC industry restrictions. Ralph was appointed in 1994 as a member of the New York City Cultural Affairs Advisory Commission by former Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. Ralph leaves behind Jean, his beloved wife of 52 years, and four daughters: Eve Baruch, Renee Baruch, Esq., Alice Baruch, M.D., and Michele Baruch Jeffery, son-in-law James Jeffery, and grandchildren Rebecca, Charles and Jane. 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths JACOBS, ALAN PERRY
summary: JACOBS--Alan Perry. Died on February 22, 2016, in Chapel Hill, NC, after a valiant struggle with cardiac amyloidosis. He was 74. Beloved husband of Lynn Goodpasture, father of Keelia with whom he shared a beautiful bond, proud brother of Jim, beloved cousin of Howard Muscott, and loving son of Charles and Jean, both deceased, Alan is deeply missed by his extended family and many friends. Born and raised in Manhattan, Alan was a lifelong New Yorker in his heart. Alan and Lynn were married for 31 years. They made a life together in New York, northwestern Connecticut, Los Angeles, and finally Chapel Hill where they were welcomed by wonderful friends, old and new. Alan led a distinguished career as a producer and professor of film. He held two degrees from Columbia University (BA, MFA). Alan started making documentary films in the late 60s supporting the Civil Rights, Anti-War, and Feminist Movements. He was directly involved in the emerging wave of independent film and video as a founding member of Newsreel, co-owner of Odeon Films, and Executive Director of the Association of Independent Video and Filmmakers. Alan was a founding trustee of the Sundance Institute and board member of the American Film Institute, the Independent Feature Project, and the Southern Documentary Fund. Alan loved the art of storytelling. In Los Angeles, he produced narrative television films for The Film Foundry, his own production company, and others including Mirage Enterprises, CBS, and Hallmark Hall of Fame. He held executive positions at Trans Lux Corporation and Hallmark Entertainment. All of this experience coupled with his natural warmth made Alan a valued teacher at California State University Long Beach where he spent five fruitful years as Assistant Professor of Film. Alan's students will remember him as perceptive, demanding, and compassionate; his business associates admired his expertise and integrity; his friends found him a witty raconteur and gentleman, modest and insightful; his family knew and loved him as utterly irreplaceable. 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GUITANO, ANTON
summary: GUITANO--Anton, of New York City, who in June of this year retired as the Chief Operating Officer of CBS Corporation's Local Media unit, passed away peacefully on December 8 at the age of 65. He had been diagnosed with cancer earlier this year. Anton was born on July 5, 1950 in Brooklyn, N.Y. to Blanche and Whitney Guitano. He grew up in Brooklyn along with his brothers, Ricardo and Glenn, before attending St. Peter's College in Jersey City, N.J., where he earned his Bachelor of Science degree in accounting on a full academic and athletic scholarship. After beginning his career with Price Waterhouse, Anton joined CBS in 1978 as a member of the company's internal audit department. Over the course of his distinguished 37-year career with CBS, he rose through the ranks to become Financial Controller for the CBS Television Network; Vice President and General Auditor for CBS, Inc.; Executive Vice President of Operations and Chief Financial Officer for CBS Television Stations; and Chief Financial Officer and Senior Executive Vice President, Operations, for CBS Radio. In 2009, Anton was named Chief Operating Officer of CBS Local Media and was responsible for overseeing the financial and operational success of CBS Corporation's local television and radio stations as well as the stations' websites and other digital platforms. Anton also served as CBS's representative on the Federal Communications Commission's Advisory Committee on Diversity for Communications in the Digital Age. Anton is survived by his loving wife of 15 years, Eileen, a member of the CBS Television Network finance department; his mother, Blanche; his brother, Glenn; his children, Jessica (Michael), Jennifer (Cory) and Jason (Maria); and three adoring grandchildren, Sydney, Nathan and Jade. He was preceded in death by his father, Whitney; brother, Ricardo; and first wife, Leslie. Visitation will be held on Thursday, December 10 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Cargain Funeral Home, 418 U.S. Route 6, Mahopac, N.Y. A Mass of Christian burial will be held on Friday, December 11 at 10 a.m. at St. John the Evangelist Catholic Church, 225 East Lake Blvd., Mahopac, N.Y. In lieu of sending flowers, friends who wish to honor Anton's memory may send donations to either the American Institute for Cancer Research (www.AICR.org) or the Preston Robert Tisch Brain Tumor Center (www.cancer.duke.edu/btc). 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BERNSTEIN, SAMUEL
summary:
BERNSTEIN--Samuel

Edward, formerly of Stamford Connecticut, passed away December 4th in Sarasota, Florida of cancer. Born September 30, 1932 in Bridgeport, Connecticut, Sam was the eldest child of Edna Kohnstamm and Walter Bernstein. He graduated University of Bridgeport, having received a full basketball scholarship. Sam worked as an accountant, and as Comptroller of the CBS phonograph division and for Princeton Knitting Mills. He owned and operated Born Free/Montego Bay, a women's sportswear firm based in Manhattan and Brooklyn, and founded Olympic Development and Sunrise Builders. Sam was an extremely driven, hardworking, dedicated man who adored his loving wife and best friend, Marjorie. His kind words, generous heart and sense of humor brought a smile to those who knew him. Sam is survived by his wife, Marjorie, of 43 years, sister, Jane, brother, Peter, daughters, Janeane and Karyn, grandchildren, great-grandchildren and nieces and nephews. A private service was held at Palms Memorial Park in Sarasota, Florida. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GLAZER, JACK
summary:
GLAZER--Jack.

We mourn the passing of Jack Glazer, our beloved partner and friend. Jack has been an integral part of our business since its inception. An absolute professional, Jack knew how to build both buildings and relationships. His dedication, fairness, warmth, and humor will be missed by all who dealt with him, most of all our staff and especially we, his partners, Charlie and Bella. Jack is irreplaceable. We send our deepest condolences, love and strength to Catherine, their children, Lola and Leo, and their entire family. CB Developers CBJ Management

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MESSINGER, MARTIN P.
summary: MESSINGER--Martin P.,age 66, of New York City and East Hampton, NY, passed away unexpectedly on Sunday, July 19, 2015 at his home in East Hampton, New York. Marty was born in the Bronx, New York to Roslyn Cohen and Hyman Messinger. He grew up in Bayside, Queens along with his brother, Joel Messinger, and attended Bayside High School before earning his bachelor's degree from the University of Bridgeport and his juris doctorate from St. John's University School of Law. He was admitted to the New York Bar in 1975. Marty began his remarkable 36-year career with Westinghouse Broadcasting and CBS in 1978. Prior to retiring in December 2014, he had served as Senior Vice President and Deputy General Counsel for CBS since 1996; and chief legal officer for the CBS Television Stations group since the division was formed in 2000. Marty also served as CBS Corporation's first Chief Compliance Officer for four years, following the company's separation from Viacom in December 2005. He joined the CBS Law Department in 1996, following the merger of CBS and Westinghouse. Prior to that, he was Vice President and General Counsel of Westinghouse Broadcasting (Group W). He played a key role in the merger of CBS and Group W, the merger of CBS with Infinity Broadcasting and numerous other significant transactions. Prior to joining Group W in 1978, Marty practiced corporate law at the Wall Street law firm Sullivan & Cromwell. The counseling and representation CBS's stations received under Marty's leadership was the best in the business. As much as his commitment to professional excellence, Marty was also revered for his deep commitment to being a friend and mentor to those around him and taking a genuine interest in the lives and careers of colleagues throughout the company. Marty's greatest pride and joy was his family. He was a devoted, involved and incredibly proud father to his children Nicole, Christopher and John, and a beaming grandfather to Nicole and her husband Bryn Harder's three daughters, Madelyn, Ruby and Layla. He is also survived by his lifelong friend, and the mother of his three children, Lupe Abuchaibe. Marty was a brilliant, intellectually curious and deeply funny man. His passion for books was evident to anyone who ever entered his home and his love for movies was also well known. He was a lifelong fan of the Brooklyn/Los Angeles Dodgers, the New York Giants, the Rangers and Knicks, and all things sports. Funeral services will be held at 2pm on Saturday, July 25 at Most Holy Trinity Church in East Hampton, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital or Save the Children, two charities that were favorites of Marty. 1/3

headline: Sanders Says He Can Beat Trump
summary: Bernie Sanders portrayed himself on CBS’s "Face the Nation" as having a better chance of beating Donald J. Trump than Hillary Clinton has in a general election.

headline: Carson: Americans need guns to defend themselves against government
summary: Republican presidential candidate Ben Carson tells CBS' Face the Nation that Americans need to be armed in case "we have the wrong people in office". Rough Cut (no reporter narration).

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths FOA, LINDA
summary: FOA--Linda. Pioneer in Design Journalism and Marketing Linda Rimanich Foa passed away peacefully at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan on June 17, 2016 after a long battle with cancer. She is survived by her husband, Conrad, their sons, Justin and Barrett, and grandchildren, Max and Luke. Her abiding interest in others, her incomparable style, and her take no prisoners demeanor, meant that everyone knew that she was "in the room". Her always-positive impact on her family and friends will be sorely missed. The stars were already aligning because Linda and Conrad were both born in Wickersham Hospital (across the street from Bloomingdale's); Linda was born there 51 weeks after her future husband. Her family resided in Jamaica Estates, New York City, where she graduated from The Mary Louis Academy. Linda majored in Fashion and Fine Arts at Parsons/NYU. Linda's sense of style, superb writing ability, and natural beauty were a unique combination that was unleashed on the world of design journalism. Linda began her professional career at Fairchild's Home Furnishings Daily and HFN where she was an editor, and penned the still-remembered FYI column. While mothering, she wrote several lead cover articles for New York Magazine, articles for The New York Times Style Section, and co-authored Kids' Stuff, the definitive furnishings guide to children's furniture and home environments [Pantheon/Random House]. In the 1990s, Linda headed and brought Designer's Saturday to prominence; producing a world-renowned annual contract furniture show in New York City that featured over 100 participating showrooms. The food and ambiance offered in the showrooms were even reviewed by Mimi Sheraton in The New York Times. For the past 11+ years, Linda was the Marketing Director of the Architects & Designers building at 150 East 58th Street. She is credited with burnishing the building's ability to attract high-end kitchen, bathroom and furniture showrooms. She contributed to a soaring occupancy rate and was instrumental in partnering with The New York Times to host the building-wide Taste of T foodie event for over a decade. Walking through the building with her, it was obvious that she was loved by tenants and co-workers alike. Linda, along with her spouse, were prominent members of the Lexington Democratic Club. She rose to the party post of District Leader and was a fierce proponent of the Club's role in forwarding and bettering the Democratic agenda. It was with great pleasure that she witnessed the presumptive nomination by the Democratic Party of the first female presidential nominee. The success of her children, Justin [fifth generation owner and CEO of 155 year-old international insurance brokerage firm, Foa & Son] and Barrett (respected, multi-talented lead actor, singer, dancer in two Tony Award-winning Broadway shows, with an eight year series-regular role on CBS's "NCIS: Los Angeles") speaks volumes about her exceptional mothering. Linda and her husband, Conrad, did everything together and were rarely apart during their 50 year relationship. A memorial service for Linda will we held at the Unitarian Church of All Souls at 1157 Lexington Avenue (80th Street) on June 28, 2016 at 11:00am. There will be a reception for Linda's friends after the service. 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MOONVES, JOSEPHINE
summary:
MOONVES--Josephine Schleifer,

A beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, died peacefully surrounded by family on July 15 at UCLA Hospital in Santa Monica, CA. She was 92. Moonves, best known to friends as Jo, was a gifted caregiver, who finished Number One in her class at nursing school, before beginning a long career in the healthcare field. She continued to practice nursing until she retired at age 70. Outside of nursing, Moonves was an avid traveler, having visited nearly 50 countries on all seven continents during her lifetime. She was also an avid reader. She loved visiting museums, watching movies and dining out. Family was the focus of her life. She was the beloved matriarch for an extended family of nieces, nephews and cousins. Josephine Schleifer Moonves was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. She was the oldest of five children and was predeceased by her four siblings. She married Herman Moonves, an Army veteran, in 1943. After marrying, the couple moved to Valley Stream, NY to raise their family. Together, the couple had three sons, CBS Chairman and CEO, Leslie Moonves (Julie Chen Moonves), entertainment attorney Jonathan Moonves (Dianne Moonves), and Alan Moonves, and a daughter, Melissa Moonves (Yves Colon). They later moved to Lynchburg, VA, Atlanta, GA and then to Pacific Palisades, CA in 1979. In California, Josephine and Herman were active members of the Santa Monica Family YMCA. In addition to her two sons and daughter, Josephine Moonves is survived by her husband of 73 years, Herman, plus eight grandchildren: Adam, Sara, Michael, Charlie, Jacques, Ian, Alaina, and Julia, and three great- grandchildren: Noah, Judah and Jack. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in Josephine's name to the Alliance for Children's Rights, 3333 Wilshire Blvd, Suite 500, Los Angeles, CA 90010. (https://support.kids- alliance. org/Josephine MoonvesMemorial)

headline: Pride: Lgsm Meets Dai (Us)
Paid Notice: Deaths MESSINGER, MARTIN
summary: MESSINGER--Martin P., age 66, of New York City and East Hampton, NY, passed away unexpectedly on Sunday, July 19, 2015 at his home in East Hampton, New York. Marty was born in the Bronx, New York to Roslyn Cohen and Hyman Messinger. He grew up in Bayside, Queens along with his brother, Joel Messinger, and attended Bayside High School before earning his bachelor's degree from the University of Bridgeport and his juris doctorate from St. John's University School of Law. He was admitted to the New York Bar in 1975. Marty began his remarkable 36-year career with Westinghouse Broadcasting and CBS in 1978. Prior to retiring in December 2014, he had served as Senior Vice President and Deputy General Counsel for CBS since 1996; and chief legal officer for the CBS Television Stations group since the division was formed in 2000. Marty also served as CBS Corporation's first Chief Compliance Officer for four years, following the company's separation from Viacom in December 2005. He joined the CBS Law Department in 1996, following the merger of CBS and Westinghouse. Prior to that, he was Vice President and General Counsel of Westinghouse Broadcasting (Group W). He played a key role in the merger of CBS and Group W, the merger of CBS with Infinity Broadcasting and numerous other significant transactions. Prior to joining Group W in 1978, Marty practiced corporate law at the Wall Street law firm Sullivan & Cromwell. The counseling and representation CBS's stations received under Marty's leadership was the best in the business. As much as his commitment to professional excellence, Marty was also revered for his deep commitment to being a friend and mentor to those around him and taking a genuine interest in the lives and careers of colleagues throughout the company. Marty's greatest pride and joy was his family. He was a devoted, involved and incredibly proud father to his children Nicole, Christopher and John, and a beaming grandfather to Nicole and her husband Bryn Harder's three daughters, Madelyn, Ruby and Layla. He is also survived by his lifelong friend, and the mother of his three children, Lupe Abuchaibe. Marty was a brilliant, intellectually curious and deeply funny man. His passion for books was evident to anyone who ever entered his home and his love for movies was also well known. He was a lifelong fan of the Brooklyn/Los Angeles Dodgers, the New York Giants, the Rangers and Knicks, and all things sports. Funeral services will be held at 2pm on Saturday, July 25 at Most Holy Trinity Church in East Hampton, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital or Save the Children, two charities that were favorites of Marty.

headline: Kasich Rebuffs Calls to Leave Race
summary: John Kasich reaffirmed his commitment to stay in the race for the Republican presidential nomination on CBS's "Face the Nation" on Sunday.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BERNSTEIN, SAMUEL EDWARD
summary: BERNSTEIN--Samuel Edward, formerly of Stamford Connecticut, passed away December 4th in Sarasota, Florida of cancer. Born September 30, 1932 in Bridgeport, Connecticut, Sam was the eldest child of Edna Kohnstamm and Walter Bernstein. He graduated University of Bridgeport, having received a full basketball scholarship. Sam worked as an accountant, and as Comptroller of the CBS phonograph division and for Princeton Knitting Mills. He owned and operated Born Free/Montego Bay, a women's sportswear firm based in Manhattan and Brooklyn, and founded Olympic Development and Sunrise Builders. Sam was an extremely driven, hardworking, dedicated man who adored his loving wife and best friend, Marjorie. His kind words, generous heart and sense of humor brought a smile to those who knew him. Sam is survived by his wife, Marjorie, of 43 years, sister, Jane, brother, Peter, daughters, Janeane and Karyn, grandchildren, great-grandchildren and nieces and nephews. A private service was held at Palms Memorial Park in Sarasota, Florida. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to a charity of your choice. 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SHANNON, GEORGE
summary:
SHANNON--George E.,

83, Broadcast Pioneer dies. George Shannon was President of CBS in the 70s and 80s, during the golden years of the "Tiffany Network." He oversaw all broadcast production facilities nationwide, all remote production including sports events and major news coverages, network distribution system, engineering and development. Countless Emmy Awards for engineering excellence were earned under his leadership and vision. Mr. Shannon, of West Islip, Long Island, passed on January 4, 2016. He was the beloved husband of the late Rita J. Shannon. He was the devoted father of Sharon Ann Fuentes, Barbara Ann Kelly and Michael T. Shannon and the cherished grandfather of six. Mr. Shannon will be reposing at The Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Hwy., (Quarter mile west of the Robert Moses Cswy). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial, Saturday 10:00am at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Babylon, Long Island. Interment to follow at St. Patrick's Cemetery, Huntington, Long Island. Visiting Friday, 2:00pm until 4:30pm and 7:00pm until 9:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 5028, Hagerstown, MD 21741-5028 or to St. Johnland Nursing Center, 395 Sunken Meadow Road, Kings Park, NY 11754.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SHATKIN, EVELYN
summary: SHATKIN--Evelyn, of Bristol, RI, passed away April 2. A graduate of Emerson College, she had a long career as Evelyn Howe, host of Five O'Clock Follies at CBS, Boston, followed by many decades in Public Relations. Survivors include daughters Susan and Joanne Shatkin, sister Janet Dobrer, several nieces and nephews, two grandchildren, one great- grandchild. Predeceased by husband Perry Shatkin, daughter Lenore Richardson Holze, parents Ed and Molly Bergman, brother Walter Bergman. Services today, April 4, Temple Beth El, 70 Orchard St., Providence, RI, 11am. Visiting hours Monday 7-9pm, Tuesday 2-4, 7-9pm. 74 Seabreeze Ln., Bristol, RI. Contributions to Gutterman Religious School Fund, Temple Beth El, or charity of your choice.

headline: The Woman In Black (Trailer 1)
Paid Notice: Deaths LOW, RICHARD H
summary: LOW--Richard H. Richard H. Low, 87, died at his home on September 15 after a long and debilitating illness. He lived in Manhattan and for many years had summer homes in Fair Harbor and Saltaire, Fire Island. He is survived by his companion of 45 years, Barbara Bonn; his best beloved daughter, Jennifer Low, PhD; her husband, Mark Scroggins, PhD; their daughters, Philippa and Daphne, and his former wife, Stephanie Taubman Low. A graduate of the University of Michigan, University of California at Berkeley and Columbia University Law School, he was a pioneer in the television industry, helping to shape the Golden Age of Television at CBS News and as Executive Vice President and Director of Broadcast Programming and Planning at the Young & Rubicam advertising agency. After retirement, he was licensed to teach history to at-risk students in the New York City high schools, and continued a lifetime of learning, taking graduate seminars in art, literature and philosophy at Columbia. He served in the U.S. Army in World War II. He was the son of Regina and Irving Low, immigrants who raised their family "over the store" in West New York, N.J. Proud of this heritage, he served as a founding trustee of the American Museum of Immigration at the Statue of Liberty, which celebrated the contributions of newcomers from all nations. He was also a Life Trustee of The Town Hall, a board member of the Air and Space Bicentennial and a member of the Advisory Committee for the League of Women Voters' Presidential Debates. He was an active participant in the battles for civil rights and gender equality. He will be remembered for his absolute integrity, formidable intelligence, generosity, profound love of art and music, and his passion for justice. A memorial gathering will be held Sunday, September 21, 11:15am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue, followed by burial at Westchester Hills Cemetery. Donations in Richard's memory may be made to the VNSNY Hospice and Palliative Care Program or any organization that promotes education for immigrants to the U.S. The family wishes to thank his team of dedicated caregivers, who improved his quality of life immeasurably over the past seven years: Evelyn Chevalier, Yvonne Dacosta, Jennifer Hylton, Blossom Mitchell, Rose Paul and Sybil Scott.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BYRNE, JAMES
summary:
BYRNE--James "Jim" III,

79, of Tenafly, New Jersey passed away on Sunday, May 29, 2016. After a short battle with cancer, he passed peacefully at home surrounded by his family and close friends. He is survived by his wife of over 50 years, Carol, his two children and their spouses, Jamie Byrne and Talisa Reeve, Carrie and Alex Putelo and his cherished grandchildren Luke and Lila. Jim was born and raised in Utica, NY, the son of James Henry Byrne II and Ruth Jones Byrne. He had a mischievous spirit as a child, which carried through his life. A graduate of Syracuse Newhouse School of Communications in 1959 and a veteran of the Armed Services, Jim was a devoted fan of the Orangemen and Army Football. Jim, an author and marketing communications professional, had a rewarding career in media and communications including 19 years as a director of marketing for CBS, the director of communications for the United States Football League (USFL), senior vice president at NW Ayer, Assistant Postmaster General of the United States and director of information at CBS News, where he worked closely with Walter Cronkite. He penned several books over his life, including works on the NFL, the Apollo space missions and "The $1 League: The Rise And Fall Of The USFL". His passions included travel, reading, politics, sports and vodka martinis, but most of all his family and close friends. Beginning in 2000, he traveled extensively with his wife, Carol and then beginning in 2011 with Carol and his grandson Luke to incredible destinations including South Africa, Greece, Istanbul, Spain, Portugal, Morocco, China, Tibet and Peru. Family will receive visitors on Thursday, June 2nd between 7pm - 9pm and Friday, June 3rd between 2pm - 4pm and 7pm - 9pm at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the John Theurer Cancer Center at Hackensack University Medical Center.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GANDOLF, RAYMOND
summary:
GANDOLF--Raymond L.,

died peacefully at home on December 2, 2015, at the age of 85. He was the devoted husband of Blanche Cholet, loving father of five daughters, Alexandra (Matthew), Jessica (Lincoln), Victoria, Amanda (Martin) and Susanna (Robert), and cherished grandfather of Dillon and Caitlin, Elias and Dana, and Scarlett. Ray was born in Norwalk, Ohio and received a Bachelor of Science in Speech from Northwestern University. He was an actor, writer, television news correspondent and sports commentator. Ray contributed to the ABC series "Our World" as writer and co-host, was featured on CBS Sunday Morning, and reported from four Olympic Games. He received an Emmy, a Peabody, and a duPont Award for his work. Ray's unforgettable charm, intelligence, wit and warmth will be greatly missed. Family will be welcoming callers on Tuesday, December 8th, 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. The Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Wednesday, December 9th, 10am at The Church of St. Gregory the Great, 144 West 90th St., between Columbus and Amsterdam Aves. Interment to follow at St. Peter's Cemetery, New Brunswick, New Jersey. Donations in his memory may be made to Southern Poverty Law Center, Atlanta, Georgia.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths PILSNER, JOYCE
summary: PILSNER--Joyce, died April 14 2016. A native of NYC, she excelled in school graduating at 15 from Hunter High School and at 19 from Hunter College. She earned an MA from Columbia and a Certificate in Business Management from Columbia Business School. Her career began as a NYC High School science teacher and guidance counselor, then an administrator at Sarah Lawrence, then becoming Executive Director of Riverdale Mental Health Association for 35 years where she developed services for both youth and adults. She was devoted to her community and served as Chair of CB8 on which she sat for 25 years. She helped found The Coalition as well as Riverdale Senior Services and received many awards, including Riverdalian of the Year. Predeceased by her beloved Harry, she is survived by her daughter Toby and granddaughters Ariel and Halley whom she adored, as well as her sister Rhoda, niece Amy, nephews Scott and Alan and their families. 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BARUCH, RALPH M.
summary: BARUCH--Ralph M.,passed away on March 3, 2016 at the age of 92. Ralph was a founder of Viacom International Inc. and served as its President and CEO from 1971 to 1983 and as Chairman until July 1987. Ralph was born in Frankfurt, Germany. In 1933, as a young child, he was forced to flee from the Nazis with his family to Paris, where he was educated. In 1940, they then escaped Paris. A harrowing three-month journey through France ensued, and Ralph carried his grandmother over the Pyrenees mountains. Eventually, under the auspices of the International Rescue Committee, the family arrived in the United States in December, 1940. He began his communications career in radio and joined the DuMont Television Network in 1950. He moved to CBS in 1954, progressing to CBS Group President, prior to the inception of Viacom. Ralph was instrumental in spinning off Viacom from CBS in 1971. During his tenure, Viacom acquired cable television systems, initiated Showtime, The Cable Health Network (now Lifetime), MTV, Nickelodeon, The Movie Channel, VH-1, and bought back the half of Showtime which had previously been sold to Warner. Eventually, Viacom, in turn, acquired CBS. Ralph authored an autobiography, "Television Tightrope - How I Escaped Hitler, Survived CBS and Fathered Viacom," published in April 2007, and also wrote "How Broadcasting and Cable Happened (in spite of the FCC)." Mr. Baruch served as vice chairman of Carnegie Hall, as a member of its Executive Committee and as chairman or member of various committees of the Board of Trustees of the Hall. He was named an Honorary Trustee in 2007. He served as a member of the Board of WNET and was a Trustee and member of the Executive Committee of Northwell Health. He also served as a Trustee of the Museum of Television and Radio (now the Paley Center for Media). Ralph was a founder and a Fellow of the International Academy of Television Arts & Sciences and served on the Board and Executive Committee of the Academy. He was a past-President of both the International Radio & Television Society and its Foundation. In 1985 the IRTS honored him with its Gold Medal, one of the most prestigious awards in communications for his outstanding contributions to the industry. A former director and member of the Executive Committee of the National Cable Television Association, (now the National Cable & Telecommunications Association), Mr. Baruch served for seven years as Chairman of an NCTA committee instrumental in the passage by Congress of the Cable Act of 1984. Under President Reagan, Ralph served for seven years as Chairman of the USIA's Television Communications Board of Advisors and as a member of the President's International Youth Exchange Initiative. In 1988, he served as a Senior Fellow of the Freedom Forum at Columbia University. Ralph was a co-founder, immediate past Chairman and Chairman Emeritus of the National Academy of Cable Programming. He received the Academy's first "Governor's Award," recognizing his contributions to the development of cable programming. He received the cable television industry's highest honor, the Vanguard Award, three of the NCTA's President's Awards, and its Chairman of the Year Award. In 1994 Ralph was honored with a special award from the International Academy of Television Arts and in 1999, Walter Cronkite presented him with an Emmy for the International Academy of Television Arts& Sciences. Seven years later, he was inducted into the Cable Hall of Fame. Then, in 2011, Ralph was the inaugural recipient of the WNET Distinguished Service Award. Ralph was a co-founder of C- Span, and often testified before regulatory agencies and committees of the Senate and House. He also served as Chairman of the NCTA's Pay Cable Committee, instrumental in removing FCC industry restrictions. Ralph was appointed in 1994 as a member of the New York City Cultural Affairs Advisory Commission by former Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. Ralph leaves behind Jean, his beloved wife of 52 years, and four daughters: Eve Baruch, Renee Baruch, Esq., Alice Baruch, M.D., and Michele Baruch Jeffery, son-in-law James Jeffery, and grandchildren Rebecca, Charles and Jane. 1/3

headline: The Last Exorcism Part Ii: Race Battle (Tv Spot)
Paid Notice: Deaths WINDT, ROBERT
summary: WINDT--Robert. He was born April 27, 1920 and died October 24, 2014. Robert Stanley Windt was bred in Brooklyn. He was a graduate of New Utrecht High School and a life-long baseball fan having seen the Dodgers play at Ebbets Field. He joined the Army for World War II becoming a carburation expert and B-29 Bomber instructor. At the end of the War, he returned home to live with his mother and start a career in public relations working for such companies as CBS, Mountain Valley Water, Dumont Television, Fairchild Publications, Pepsi Cola, Royal Crown Cola, Seagram's and STP Motor Oil. He retired from the profession when he and his two partners sold their ownership of Bebidas, a Spanish language beverage industry magazine. Uncle Bob, as he was known, was a loving, son, brother, uncle, great-uncle and great-great-uncle with a story or three at every family gathering. He will be missed by his family and friends. At the request of the family, donations in his memory can be made to the List Family Fund for Jewish Culture in Memory of Lawrence List at the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue (131 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, NY 11201). To use Uncle Bob's favorite word - he had a "Fabulous" life. Bobye, Deborah and Mali List.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths STONE, EMERSON LAW
summary: STONE--Emerson Law. The CBS News executive who produced the only live call-in show with a sitting United States President has died. A lover of nature, language, music, and family, he died Monday after a fall. He lived in Greenwich, CT, with his wife Louisa H. Stone. From 1952 to 1987, Emerson rose from the CBS mailroom to the Vice Presidency, first for network radio and later for radio and television news practices. During the call-in for "Ask President Carter," he handled the kill switch, in case of offensive calls. He made CBS the first network to broadcast 24-hour news and supervised radio coverage of the Vietnam War, the Robert Kennedy and Martin Luther King, Jr., assassinations, all Apollo moon landings, Watergate, and political conventions. Winner of two Peabody Awards, he worked with such greats as Edward R. Murrow and Walter Cronkite and brought Charles Os- good to the network. He was the network's first ombudsman. Born February 15, 1928 in New Haven to Emerson L. Stone and Grace K. Stone, he graduated from Yale University, class of 1948, and later won the university's highest honor, the Yale Medal. His brother Jon, head writer and director of "Sesame Street," died in 1997. Their sister Diana chairs the Dwight Englewood School language department. Emerson leaves his wife of 59 years; three daughters, Lise, Mei, and Kris, a son-in-law Stephen B. Heintz; and six grandchildren. The family will celebrate his life on January 17, 2015 at the Round Hill Community Church. Memorial donations are suggested to Doctors Without Borders or Yale University. 1/3

headline: G.O.P. Needs 'Real Unification,' Ryan Says
summary: Representative Paul D. Ryan, the speaker of the House, said that Republicans should not prematurely 'pretend' that they are unified and that he was looking forward to getting to know Donald J. Trump, the presumptive presidential nominee.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MUNRO, WILLIAM
summary:
MUNRO--William Pierce,

died quietly on May 26, 2015, in the hospital where he was born on April 17, 1922, near his home in Bronxville, NY. Beloved husband of 62 years to the late Betty Munro, loving father of Constance Munro Kamerman (Jack) and the late Leslie, grandfather to Anne, David, and William and Noelle; uncle to Deb, Bruce, and David; brother-in-law to Marjorie and Gordon. After graduating from Colgate University in 1943 he went on to serve his country in WWII, where he was a veteran of the Normandy Invasion, defense of Europe, and liberation of concentration camps. He was a faithful friend to many who admired his intellect, integrity, humor, loyalty, kindness, and generosity. As an honest, successful, and trusted businessman, he embodied the American work ethic and personified the American dream throughout his years at Sylvania, CBS International, and Sylvan Ginsbury, Ltd. Bill loved his family, his cats, his lifelong friends Bob and Joe, the Yankees and the New York Giants, Glenn Miller, The New York Times crossword, a good tennis game and a fine single malt Scotch. He was proud of his Scottish heritage, his military service, his business career, his home and family, and of having been at Yankee Stadium for Don Larsen's perfect game in the 1956 World Series. He was grateful to Yvonne and Mona for their devoted nursing of both himself and his late wife, Betty, and sad to have been preceded in death by Betty, Leslie, and Gordon. He is mourned by everyone who knew him. Donations to New York- Presbyterian/Lawrence Hospital, 55 Palmer Road, Bronxville NY 10708 www.nyplawrence.org or the American Heart Association, both of which, together with the excellent Dr. Salvate, helped keep him with us for many years.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WEST, HOWARD
summary:
WEST--Howard.

Howard West, longtime business partner of fellow Seinfeld producer George Shapiro, has died of a stroke at UCLA Medical Center on December 3, 2015. He was 84. West and Shapiro, had one of the longest friendships and business relationships in the history of Hollywood. The two boys from the Bronx had known each other since grammar school and then went on to work together for 41 years at personal management/production company Shapiro/West. "I first met Howie in the schoolyard of Public School 80 in the Bronx when we were eight years old," Shapiro said. "Howie was the new kid at school as he just moved from another Bronx neighborhood. Howie was alone in the schoolyard, sitting on a step near one of the school entrances. I invited him to join me and my friends to play basketball, stickball, curb ball, and touch football. It was love at first sight, and we became best friends since that day. We were partners in buying comic books, we bought our first car together, worked as busboys, and lifeguards/stagehands at the Tamiment summer resort in the Pocono Mountains, where he worked with writers Neil and Danny Simon, choreographer Herb Ross, comedian Dick Shawn, and singer Barbara Cook. It was a great beginning for our showbiz career." (PS 80 in the Bronx is also the alma mater of Garry and Penny Marshall, Ralph Lauren (nee Ralph Lipschitz), Calvin Klein, and Robert Klein). After graduation from Long Island University and then serving in the Army, West reunited with Shapiro in the William Morris Agency mailroom, and it wasn't long before both began repping talent. West's clients at William Morris included Neil Diamond, Glen Campbell, Anne Murray, Ruth Buzzi, Paul Lynde, Jerry Reed and Greg Garrison (who produced/directed The Dean Martin Show and The Dean Martin Celebrity Roast). He specialized in television packaging, putting together such shows as The Glen Campbell Goodtime Hour and The Bobby Darin Show. In 1974, he left the William Morris Agency to help form Shapiro/West. Shapiro recruited West by offering him the presidency of the firm and the parking space closest to the office entrance. West, who also then began repping Marty Feldman, executive produced the comedian's The Last Remake of Beau Geste, which he also developed with the comedy star. He also produced "In God We Trust," which he and Feldman once again developed. In addition to Jerry Seinfeld, Carl Reiner, Peter Bonerz (who was an actor on Newhart before directing multiple episodes of Murphy Brown and Home Improvement), Shapiro/West's client roster included/includes Feldman, Andy Kaufman, director Alan Myerson, Gabe Kaplan, Robert Wuhl, Bill Persky and Sam Denoff (who produced The Dick Van Dyke Show with Reiner and created That Girl for Marlo Thomas), Dick Clair and Jenna McMahon (who wrote for Carol Burnett, created Mama's Family, Facts of Life and It's a Living), Ken Spears & Joe Ruby, Tom Tenowich and Ed Scharlach ("Mork & Mindy"), Sam Bobrick (the prolific playwright who also created NBC's Saved By The Bell and wrote for such classic comedy shows as Get Smart, The Andy Griffith Show, and The Dick Van Dyke Show), and writer Norman Barasch ("Send Me No Flowers" on Broadway, TV shows "Rhoda", "Benson", "Chico & The Man"), and Austin & Irma Kalish (writers for "All In The Family", "Bob Newhart Show", "Maude", etc.), Steve Gordon (writer/director of "Arthur" starring Dudley Moore. West also guided the successful career of Bill Lawrence who produced Spin City, Scrubs, Cougar Town. Lawrence's new series "Undateable" is in its third season on NBC and the one-hour series Rush Hour (based on the hit film) was picked up by CBS. Together, Shapiro and West were part of the producing team behind the beloved comedy series Seinfeld, for which they won multiple Emmy, Golden Globe and Peabody awards and was named best sitcom of all time in 2012 after a nationwide poll taken by 60 Minutes and Vanity Fair. "Seinfeld" ran from 1989 to 1998, leaving at #1 rated show in the country. They also executive produced Andy Kaufman at Carnegie Hall, as well as Kaufman's ABC special, the Paramount feature film "Summer School" starring Mark Harmon, and the Universal biopic, Man on the Moon, which was directed by Milos Forman and starred Jim Carrey as Kaufman. West and Shapiro both had cameos in Man on the Moon: Shapiro portrayed comedy club owner Mr. Besserman (a role he had to read for). West play a hard-nosed network executive (Howard didn't have to read), "he was a natural for the role," Shapiro said. They also produced the award- winning documentaries, The Bronx Boys for HBO, and The Bronx Boys Still Playing at 80 for PBS. Shapiro/West is currently working with Seinfeld on the web series Comedians In Cars Getting Coffee. Jerry Seinfeld said "Howard was doing what he loved until the end. There's nothing better." But West's true love was Marlene, his wife of 54 years. He is survived by his two children Dayna and Todd, granddaughter, Olivia, and by his great friend George Shapiro.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SANDERS, MARLENE
summary: SANDERS--Marlene. The Community Service Society extends its deepest sympathies to the family and friends of Marlene Sanders who passed away on Tuesday. Marlene was best known as a trailblazing female journalist whose early success as a television correspondent - she was the first woman to anchor a prime time network newscast - helped pave the way for others who would come after her and change the face of television news forever. But she was also a great friend to CSS, having served for more than 20 years as the Chair of the Retired and Senior Volunteer Program (RSVP), the organization's signature volunteer program, and as a former member until 2015 of the CSS Board of Trustees. A three- time Emmy Award winning correspondent, producer, writer, and former news executive, Marlene's illustrious career in journalism spanned more than three decades, including stints at ABC News, CBS News, and PBS. In addition to reporting assignments, she produced and narrated documentaries for HBO, public television, and others. When her journalism career was over Marlene remained active as an advocate for women in the news profession. She also contributed to the development of young journalists as adjunct professor at the NYU Journalism Institute. Marlene will be remembered as a warm, engaging, and undaunted individual who accomplished so much in her groundbreaking career and was incredibly generous with her time and resources. It is with sadness and a profound sense of loss that we mourn her death. 1/3

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SIRAISI, NOBUYUKI
summary:
SIRAISI (SHIRAISHI)--

Nobuyuki, 81, died March 10, 2016 at home after an illness. He leaves wife of 55 years, Nancy, sons Maro and Genji and their wives and children, Voahangy, Marissa, Fanja, Fetra, Desmond and Niko, and great-grandson Jaylen, and his siblings' families in Japan. Born in Japan youngest of three, Nobu matriculated in Art at Tokyo Geidai University, coming to New York City in 1959 where he fell in love with Nancy and stayed. His life in New York City included a steady stream of sculptures and paintings (for which CBS-TV featured him in the early 1960s), working as studio assistant to Isamu Noguchi, then as a graphic designer at Gilbert Advertising, then at Mike Hertz Inc. where he led a team to produce in 1979 his best known work, today's NYC Subway Map. Nobu was a life-long lover of all the arts and frequenter and supporter of the underground music scene, as well as a dedicated contributor to charities to preserve the environment and aid the weak and downtrodden. His funeral was held in Brooklyn. He was dearly loved.
